awd_titl_txt: Plastidic phosphate transport and plant biomass allocation
awd_abstract_narration: Plastids are a defining feature of plant cells. These diverse organelles are the sites of a wide array of essential processes that include photosynthesis and the subsequent partitioning of carbon between sugars for immediate use throughout the plant, and starch for temporary storage that is reclaimed during the night. Phosphate concentrations strongly influence these processes, but understanding of the transport proteins needed to coordinate plastidic phosphate levels with environmental and metabolic conditions is incomplete. The objectives of this project are to determine the transport mechanism and physiological role of phosphate transporters that reside in either chloroplasts or non-photosynthetic plastids of the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. Loss-of-function mutants for these transporters display unique growth and metabolic phenotypes that suggest distinct roles. Notably, a mutant for a root plastid transporter exhibits increased cell proliferation in leaves with a corresponding increase in leaf biomass. Grafting studies combined with genetic and biochemical studies will be used to test the hypothesis that carbon allocation between root and shoot tissues influences mitotic activity in leaves. This project will provide new insight into how plants integrate phosphate and carbon metabolism at the cellular level to control the physiology of photosynthetic and non-photosynthetic tissues. Moreover, these studies may have practical implications for agriculture. Graduate and undergraduate students will receive multidisciplinary research training, formal teaching opportunities, and will participate in the development and implementation of undergraduate biology education workshops.

por.por_cntn:
Plastids are the organelles in plant cells that capture carbon from the air through the process of photosynthesis then direct this carbon to either meet the immediate growth needs of the plant or retain it in storage forms like starch that can be reclaimed at night. These different fates for carbon, and in turn the growth capacity of a plant, are influenced by phosphate, an essential nutrient. We are interested in proteins that control the movement of phosphate into and out of chloroplasts and related non-photosynthetic plastids. The research supported by this award was designed to study the function of this class of phosphate transport proteins in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. The results of our experiments provided several new insights into how phosphate and carbon metabolism are coordinated and can influence leaf growth. In particular, we learned that phosphate accumulation in a subset of plastids correlates with proliferation of the stem cells that give rise to leaves. This change in cell numbers ultimately leads to enlarged but otherwise normal leaves. These results implicate communication between plastids and the cell nucleus to control cell division.

Results of our experiments related to the control of leaf size may have translational implications for development of improved food and biofuel crops. In addition to research activities, this award supported two graduate students who each completed a PhD and four undergraduate students, all who are now enrolled in postgraduate science or health-related programs.
